Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Physics REU and RET Programs at the University of Notre Dame
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the renewal of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and the Research Experience for Teachers (RET) site at the University of Notre Dame. Projects are available in the areas of Astronomy, Astrophysics, Biophysics, Cosmology, Condensed Matter Physics, High-Energy Particle Physics, Nuclear Physics, and Physics Education Research. The goal of the site is to provide realistic research experiences to undergraduate students and high school physics teachers. The participants will work with a faculty mentor on a specific research project and will be exposed to physics research in other areas via weekly seminars, workshops, interactions with other participants, and field trips to nearby national laboratories. They will prepare a research report at the end of the program and make oral presentations at the REU-RET Symposium. They will also maintain a research logbook and will have opportunity to attend courses in computer programming, machine shop, and radiation safety. A workshop will be held on Applying to Graduate Schools and Preparing for GRE's. A series of workshops will also be held as part of the Ethics component. This award is funded by the Division of Physics and co-funded by the Science, Technology, and Society Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Notre Dame Physics REU and RET program provides an opportunity for undergraduate physics majors and high-school teachers each summer to discover the excitement of physics research. We attempt to create a 'physics community' that includes senior scientists, graduate students and young postdocs, undergraduate students, physics teachers, and high school students.

The participants worked with faculty members on specific research projects and were exposed to physics research in other areas via weekly seminars, workshops, interactions with other participants, and field trips to nearby national laboratories. They prepared a research report at the end of the program and made oral presentations at the REU-RET Symposium. They also maintained a research logbook and had an opportunity to attend courses in computer programming, GRE Preparation, and radiation safety. Ethics Workshops formed another integral component of the program.

A total of 114 REU students participated in the program, of whom 43 (38%) were women and 31 (27%) were from under-represented minority groups. 64% of the supported students came from institutions where opportunities for meaningful research are minimal, or non-existent. More than 70% of REU participants have gone on to pursue graduate studies and research.

The RET program, typically, had 16 high school teachers every Summer. They came mostly from within a 50-km radius centered at Notre Dame, but some participants came also from places as far away as Arkansas, Florida, and New Jersey. Several teachers have leveraged their experiences from the RET program to contribute to physics outreach in high schools in Chile and Greece. The RET participants regularly took on a considerable role in the regional science outreach program called “Science Alive,” held annually at the St. Joseph County Public Library in downtown South Bend.

The students and teachers carried out research in the areas of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Biophysics, Condensed Matter Physics, High Energy Physics, Network Science, Nuclear Physics, and Physics Education. Over the project period, this led to a total of 69 publications/communications and presentations at scientific and professional meetings with REU students as coauthors.
